title: Hedge fund tests Peru on landowner debt
text:
Hedge fund threatens Peru over debts to former landowners By Andres Schipani in Bogotá and Robin Wigglesworth in New York ©Bloomberg 
When Peruvian general Juan Velasco seized power in 1969 and started expropriating tracts of land to implement a redistribution programme, the owners were compensated in “ Agrarian Reform Bonds ”. Augusto Pretel is still waiting for the government to honour them. 
“Forty-three years later I continue the battle to get paid,” says the 75-year-old Mr Pretel, whose family lost a swath of land in Ancash. “My grandmother died battling, my father died battling, and I will continue battling.” More Brazil’s Rousseff faces impeachment heat 
Mr Pretel is one of many bondholders, including Gramercy , an emerging markets-focused hedge fund, that are clamouring publicly for Lima to fairly settle the debts. 
Creditors say an existing repayment plan dramatically shortchanges them and tarnishes Peru’s image as a regional star, after the country slowly transformed itself from a byword for fiscal irresponsibility to boasting an investment grade rating. 
“Here we have an effective default of a debt of the Peruvian treasury, and there are big risks associated to that,” says Ismael Benavides, a former finance minister whose family owns some of the agrarian bonds. 
Peru stopped servicing the debts several decades ago after an economic crisis, and since then has been locked in a lengthy legal battle with local and foreign bondholders over whether and how it should repay them. The crux of the dispute is how to value them while adjusting for the impact of several currency devaluations and hyperinflation. 
Bondholders claim they are worth $5bn, but the administration of president Ollanta Humala is only offering compensation using an adjustment methodology that offers a fraction of this. Gramercy estimates that the government’s offered payout will at most amount to $24m. Mr Pretel reckons he is owed $5m, but says the Peruvian state now wants to pay him less than 30 cents. 
“While we strongly prefer a consensual resolution, Peru should not mistake our commitment to a pragmatic and constructive dialogue as a lack of resolve,” says James Taylor, a partner and chief legal officer of Gramercy. 
The hedge fund is openly threatening to seek redress through a US-Peruvian free trade agreement , and is stepping up an information campaign and backing bondholder groups to put pressure on the government. 
The Peruvian Land Reform Bondholders Association, a local lobbying organisation, attempted to stage a protest at the International Monetary Fund and World Bank’s annual meeting, which was held in Lima this week, but say they were denied a permit to do so. 
“[The bondholders association] and its members will observe rule of law and not engage in peaceful protests,” the group’s representative Ramón Remolina said in a statement.“We only wish that the government obeyed the legitimate rulings of its courts and honoured our right to freedom of speech and freedom of assembly.” 
Gramercy has held a big chunk of the land bonds for many years, after snapping them up on the market for esoteric long-defaulted debt, like North Korean or Cuban loans. But it has shied away from calling publicly for repayment — until recently. The reason for its new, vocal approach is fresh concerns over a 2013 Constitutional Tribunal ruling on the bonds. 
Over the decades, a series of governments have baulked at the cost of paying the bonds, preferring to defer the issue to future administrations. Two years ago the Constitutional Tribunal reaffirmed an earlier ruling that the government had to repay the bondholders at an adjusted value — but crucially allowed the government to calculate its own methodology, which was announced in January 2014. 
Allegations of irregularities around the decision spurred bondholders like Mr Pretel and Gramercy to renew their push for a fairer deal. 
“Unfortunately, it is just one part of what appears to be a grand scheme by the Humala administration to evade this decades old debt,” Mr Taylor says. 
Senior Peruvian officials are unconcerned, and say the old debts are being dealt with “unquestioningly” under the country’s laws. One government official said the timing for the ruckus was a strategy to tarnish Peru’s reputation during the IMF and World Bank meeting. 
But Carlos Mesía, a former magistrate of the Constitutional Court at the time of the decision, indicates bondholders have cause to feel aggrieved. 
”There was no legal norm that established how to update the price of the bonds, so the tribunal needed to establish a criteria. But that criteria did not really respect the previous sentence regarding the adjusted value,” he says. 
Bondholders argue that Peru could exchange the old defaulted land debts for new, long-dated sovereign bonds, giving Peru plenty of time to repay creditors and only add modestly to the state’s overall indebtedness. 
The question is whether Gramercy has any chance of compelling the Peruvian government to do so — either through the courts or through public embarrassment. The asset manager says it is considering lodging an international claim against the Andean country under the US-Peru Free Trade Agreement, which entered into force in 2009. But local and international lawyers give this avenue little chance of success, and the government appears unconcerned. 
“The truth is there has never been much willingness from any Peruvian government to pay these bonds,” says Geoffrey Cannock, an economist with Apoyo Consultoría in Lima. “They have rather had legal battles over them, than actually pay them.” Copyright The Financial Times Limited 2015.
